titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Holocaust Survivors Film Project Records
titlestmt.author: compiled by Stephen Naron

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday April 6, 2019 at 07:00

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The Holocaust Survivors Film Project (HSFP) was a grass roots project to videotape testimony of survivors. The records document the establishment of the project and its growth from a volunteer effort to an established academic research collection, now known as the Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust Testimonies, at the Yale University Library. The collection includes administrative and financial records, such as correspondence, press releases, meeting minutes, grant proposals, pamphlets, and clippings.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust Testimonies, 2008.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Holocaust Survivors Film Project Records (MS 1909). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Other records related to the Holocaust Survivors Film Project and its successor organization, the Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust Testimonies, are maintained by the Yale University Archives in Manuscripts and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1979, a television specialist, Laurel Vlock, and a survivor of the Holocaust, psychiatrist Dr. Dori Laub, launched a project to document the personal memories of Holocaust witnesses using the medium of video. They helped form a grass roots organization, the Holocaust Survivors Film Project (HSFP), together with local survivors, under the leadership of William Rosenberg, academic consultants led by Yale Professor Geoffrey Hartman, and other community members committed to this urgent task. Initially, this group videotaped almost 200 testimonies; produced, with New York's WNEW-TV, Forever Yesterday , an Emmy award-winning documentary; and created About the Holocaust , a specially prepared documentary for secondary schools. In 1981 Yale University accepted all the original testimony tapes as a formal deposit. The following year, with the aid of a start-up grant from the Charles H. Revson Foundation, the Video Archive was established as part of the University's Sterling Memorial Library. Additional information about the HSFP and its successor organization, the Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust Testimonies, can be found at the Video Archive's web site: http://www.library.yale.edu/testimonies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Holocaust Survivors Film Project (HSFP) was a grass roots project to videotape testimony of survivors. The records document the establishment of the project and its growth from a volunteer effort to an established academic research collection, now known as the Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust Testimonies, at the Yale University Library. The collection includes administrative and financial records, such as correspondence, press releases, meeting minutes, grant proposals, pamphlets, and clippings.

Of particular interest is the correspondence between members of the HSFP (particularly Dori Laub, Laurel Vlock, Geoffrey Hartman, Malcolm Webber, Melvin Ditman, and Ludwig Friedenberg) and survivors; grant funding agencies; various affiliate projects and Jewish organizations, such as Yad Vashem; television stations; scholars of the Holocaust, including Elie Wiesel, Yizhak Arad, and Yehuda Bauer; representatives from the President's Comission on the Holocaust; and potential repositories to house the HSFP tapes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records follow two arrangements that reflect how they were received. Administrative and financial records are followed by records in an alphabetical filing system. This latter group of records includes generic files and subject files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The financial records include correspondence, particularly with then treasurer Ludwig Friedenberg, related to donations and expenditures for HSFP tapings, including pages from an accounting book for the documentary about the New Haven Farband.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and agreement between the HSFP and Laurel Vlock and Dori Laub.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents related to establishment and management of an affiliate taping project in Boston, Massachusetts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publicity packet, including short history of the project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lists of foundations to which the HSFP applied, or considered applying, for funding.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Information regarding potential interviewees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Yale President A. Bartlett Giamatti, Itzhak Gottesman, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents related to establishment and management of an affiliate taping project in Hartford, Connecticut, including the production of film The Survivors Among Us , which was screened on public television.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Agendas, press conferences, organizational charts, newsletters, grant proposals, and a transcript of a presentation given at press conference at the home of William Rosenberg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents related to interviewer methodology and training.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence (some in Hebrew), photographs and documents regarding Dori Laub's participation in the Fourth International Historical Conference in Jerusalem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence related to taping efforts at Katherine Engel Center in New York City, staff lists, taping schedules, and taping procedures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcript of interview conducted by and correspondence with Dana Kline.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Packet of photocopied correspondence, brochures, and other materials documenting Dori Laub's involvement in the HSFP.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and photocopy of New Haven Foundation grant proposal submitted in 1979.

did.unittitle: National Endowment for the Arts and National Endowment for the Humanities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, clippings, and other materials related to the submission of an NEH grant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents related to possibility of establishing an affiliate taping project in Norfolk, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with Yehuda Bauer, among others, and photocopies of manuscripts on oral history and the Holocaust.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents related to establishment and management of an affiliate taping project in Palm Beach, Florida.

did.unittitle: Position paper regarding the relevance of the HSFP for New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clippings, photocopies of letters from important community figures, press releases and other materials used to promote the mission of the HSFP.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various correspondence and photocopy of Revson grant proposal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Paper by Dori Laub suggesting study of survivor adaptation to trauma.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Résumés from interviewer candidates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photocopies of manuscript materials and photographs, clippings, and correpsondence related to two film projects: Flight from Destiny , a documentary about the journey of the ocean liner St.Louis, and a film about the Jewish community of Danzig. Includes a series of articles in German from the periodical Stern about the St. Louis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A list of the first wave of testimonies recorded starting in 1979 with short biographical sketches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence with television stations regarding screenings to documentaries made with HSFP materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcriptions of Laurel Vlock describing HSFP.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Memos, budgets, and job descriptions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to the establishment of a Video Archive for HSFP testimonies at Yale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requests from various organizations interested in forming an affiliate with the HSFP/Video Archive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Geoffrey Hartman regarding provision of mental health support to survivors after taping sessions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Lillian Weiss and Dori Laub.
